citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the licensee did not have records that fully disclose required information regarding domestic cats
purchased, sold, held, or otherwise acquired. Domestic cats were being housed loose, overnight, in the same indoor
facility with loose chickens, caged guinea pigs, and caged rabbits. Though the domestic cats were not to be used for
exhibition, they were being housed in the same indoor facility as regulated animals. Appropriate documentation of
acquired regulated animals is essential for proper identification and necessary to track animals used in regulated activities
to ensure their humane care, use, and disposition.
Domestic dogs and cats must be housed separated from regulated animals. Otherwise, the licensee must make, keep,
and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose required information concerning each dog or cat
purchased, owned, held, or otherwise acquired. The records shall also include any offspring born of any animal while in
the licensee’s possession or under the licensee’s control.
To be corrected from this day (1/8/2025) forward.

At the time of inspection, the licensee did not have a Contingency Plan. A contingency plan is essential to ensuring the
health and well-being of animals, in the event of an unanticipated emergency or disaster.
The licensee must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment,
transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster (one which could reasonably
be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in their possession).
To be corrected by 2/28/2025.

At the time of the inspection the indoor housing facility holding 9 guinea pigs was at a temperature of 52 degrees
Fahrenheit, as measured by a kestrel. Guinea pigs kept in ambient temperatures that are too low may be subject to cold
stress that may cause discomfort and predispose them to developing other health issues.
Indoor housing facilities for guinea pigs shall be sufficiently heated to protect the animals from the cold, and to provide for
their health and well-being. The ambient temperature in indoor housing facilities for guinea pigs must not fall below 60
degrees Fahrenheit.
To be correct by 1/10/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(a)(1)(i) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
At the time of inspection, the licensee did not have records that fully disclose required information regarding domestic cats 
purchased, sold, held, or otherwise acquired. Domestic cats were being housed loose, overnight, in the same indoor 
facility with loose chickens, caged guinea pigs, and caged rabbits. Though the domestic cats were not to be used for 
exhibition, they were being housed in the same indoor facility as regulated animals. Appropriate documentation of 
acquired regulated animals is essential for proper identification and necessary to track animals used in regulated activities 
to ensure their humane care, use, and disposition.  
 
Domestic dogs and cats must be housed separated from regulated animals. Otherwise, the licensee must make, keep, 
and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose required information concerning each dog or cat 
purchased, owned, held, or otherwise acquired. The records shall also include any offspring born of any animal while in 
the licensee’s possession or under the licensee’s control. 
 
To be corrected from this day (1/8/2025) forward. 
2.134(a) 
   
Contingency planning. 
At the time of inspection, the licensee did not have a Contingency Plan. A contingency plan is essential to ensuring the 
health and well-being of animals, in the event of an unanticipated emergency or disaster. 
 
The licensee must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, 
transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster (one which could reasonably 
be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in their possession). 
 
To be corrected by 2/28/2025. 
3.26(a)

Facilities, indoor. 
At the time of the inspection the indoor housing facility holding 9 guinea pigs was at a temperature of 52 degrees 
Fahrenheit, as measured by a kestrel. Guinea pigs kept in ambient temperatures that are too low may be subject to cold 
stress that may cause discomfort and predispose them to developing other health issues. 
 
Indoor housing facilities for guinea pigs shall be sufficiently heated to protect the animals from the cold, and to provide for 
their health and well-being. The ambient temperature in indoor housing facilities for guinea pigs must not fall below 60 
degrees Fahrenheit. 
 
To be correct by 1/10/2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
